prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for leaving my daughter's friend at the park?
A few days ago I was coming home from work. My daughter wanted to be picked up so I drove over to the park (where she was at). 

When I got there, there was this other who was my daughter's friend. She apparently needed a ride home. I declined her. 

After that, I drove my daughter home. Another important detail is that it was around six a clock at the time I picked my daughter up.
"""

I think the author is not in the wrong, but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let me try to work through this. The user is asking whether the person who wrote the AITA (Am I the Asshole) story is in the wrong for leaving their daughter's friend at the park.

So the situation is that the parent went to the park to pick up their daughter. When they arrived, the daughter's friend was also there and wanted a ride home, but the parent declined. The key point here is that the parent only agreed to pick up their own daughter. They didn't have any prior obligation to the friend, right? The friend probably just assumed that since the parent was picking up their daughter, they'd also take the friend, but the parent wasn't responsible for that. 

I should consider the context: it was around 6 PM, which is when the parent picked up their daughter. The parent might have had their own schedule or reasons for not wanting to take another child. Also, the parent's main responsibility is their own child. They didn't volunteer to be the friend's ride, so it's up to the friend to arrange her own transportation. The parent isn't in the wrong here because they weren't obligated to help the friend. The friend might have been expecting it, but that's not the parent's fault. So the answer should be B, the author is not in the wrong.
